comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] they are similar somehow ... but the man in your link has a broader face width (I wonder if it has to do with the photographic technique or they are indeed two different men).

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Seems like it's actually Hussein Kamel, ruler of Egypt in 1915, but not Khedive, as Abbas II was the last Khedive, according to Wikipedia Wikipedia uses an uncropped version of this photo for Kamel's entry: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hussein_Kamel_of_Egypt "Sultan Hussein Kamel (Arabic: السلطان حسين كامل‎; 21 November 1853 – 9 October 1917) was the Sultan of Egypt from 19 December 1914 to 9 October 1917, during the British protectorate over Egypt. Hussein Kamel was the son of Khedive Isma'il Pasha, who ruled Egypt from 1863 to 1879. Hussein Kamel was declared Sultan of Egypt on 19 December 1914, after the occupying British forces had deposed his nephew, Khedive Abbas Hilmi II, on 5 November 1914. The newly created Sultanate of Egypt was declared a British protectorate. "

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: oh yes it is a perfect match.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Elsewhere in The Commons, George Eastman House has posted what appears to be the original photo, It is attributed to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chusseau-flaviens, Charles Chusseau-Flaviens, founder of a pictorial news agency of the same name. Another Bain Collection photo of the Sultan, looking dapper in a double-breasted suit.

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: He died before the end of WWI as wikipedia says, so on Chusseau-flaviens link the time can be shortened to 1910-1917 (or even 1916, if we thought that he died of sickness at 63).
